elements.content: Porous glasses from metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) represent a new class of functional inorganic–organic materials, which have been proposed for applications ranging from solid electrolytes to radioactive waste storage. So far, just a few zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a subset of MOFs, have been reported to melt and the structural and compositional requirements for MOF melting and glass formation are poorly understood. Here, we show how the melting point of the prototypical ZIF-4/ZIF-62­(M) frameworks (composition M­(im)2–x (bim) x ; M2+ = Co2+, Zn2+; im– = imidazolate; bim– = benzimidazolate) can be controlled systematically by adjusting the molar ratio of the two imidazolate-type linkers im– and bim–. By covering the entire range from x = 0 to 0.35, we unveil a delicate transition from ZIF materials showing sequential amorphization/recrystallization to derivatives exhibiting coherent melting and a liquid phase that is stable over a large temperature window. The melting point of this ZIF system is a direct function of x and can be lowered from ca. 430 °C to only 370 °C, by far the lowest melting point reported for a three-dimensional porous MOF. On the basis of our results, we postulate compositional requirements for ZIF melting and glass formation, which may guide the search for other meltable ZIFs. Moreover, gas physisorption experiments establish that the ZIF glasses adsorb technologically relevant C3 and C4 hydrocarbons. Importantly, the adsorption kinetics are much faster for propylene compared to propane and are also dependent on the im–:bim– ratio, thus demonstrating the potential of these ZIF glasses for applications in gas separation.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are composed of inorganic and organic building units, which interconnect to crystalline porous coordination networks. These compounds have received enormous interest in past years because of various potential applications ranging from gas storage and separation to sensing, catalysis and drug delivery. Typically, these crystalline compounds collapse at elevated temperatures (200–600 °C) under irreversible decomposition. A few zinc- and cobalt-based zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a subset of MOFs, however, possess high thermal stability and melt before thermal decomposition. Cooling the ZIF liquids below their melting points generates ZIF glasses, a new class of inorganic–organic glasses composed of randomly connected, tetrahedrally coordinated metal ions (Zn2+ or Co2+). Such ZIF liquids and glasses have recently gained much attention because of their uncommon physical properties, such as porosity, high glass forming ability, or ionic conductivity. Applications have been proposed in various fields ranging from solid electrolytes and membranes to nonlinear optics and radioactive waste storage.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are composed of inorganic and organic building units, which interconnect to crystalline porous coordination networks. These compounds have received enormous interest in past years because of various potential applications ranging from gas storage and separation to sensing, catalysis and drug delivery. Typically, these crystalline compounds collapse at elevated temperatures (200-600 °C) under irreversible decomposition. A few zinc- and cobalt-based zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs), a subset of MOFs, however, possess high thermal stability and melt before thermal decomposition. Cooling the ZIF liquids below their melting points generates ZIF glasses, a new class of inorganic-organic glasses composed of randomly connected, tetrahedrally coordinated metal ions (Zn2+ or Co2+). Such ZIF liquids and glasses have recently gained much attention because of their uncommon physical properties, such as porosity, high glass forming ability, or ionic conductivity. Applications have been proposed in various fields ranging from solid electrolytes and membranes to nonlinear optics and radioactive waste storage.

elements.content: The prototypical ZIF glass former is a compound of composition Zn­(im)2 (im– = imidazolate) named ZIF-4­(Zn). The microporous framework is composed of Zn2+ ions, which are tetrahedrally coordinated by im– linkers. These im– linkers bridge two Zn2+ ions, to generate a zeolite-like framework of cag topology. When heated in inert atmosphere (Ar) the framework collapses at around 330 °C and forms a metastable amorphous phase which recrystallizes to a denser phase of zni topology (ZIF-zni­(Zn)) at ∼450–500 °C (crystallographic densities: ρZIF‑4(Zn) = 1.18 g cm–3, ρZIF‑zni(Zn) = 1.54 g cm–3). Melting of this ZIF-zni­(Zn) phase is observed at ∼590 °C and at approximately 600 °C the melted material decomposes. Mechanistically, ZIF amorphization, recrystallization and melting involves dynamic breaking and reformation of zinc-imidazolate bonds. Quenching the liquid ZIF to room temperature before reaching the decomposition temperature yields a ZIF glass, which still features Zn2+ ions that are tetrahedrally coordinated by imidazolate linkers, however, lacks long-range order. The structure of the ZIF glass was found to be analogous to the continuous random network model developed for silicate glasses.
elements.clean_text: The prototypical ZIF glass former is a compound of composition Zn(im)2 (im- = imidazolate) named ZIF-4(Zn). The microporous framework is composed of Zn2+ ions, which are tetrahedrally coordinated by im- linkers. These im- linkers bridge two Zn2+ ions, to generate a zeolite-like framework of cag topology. When heated in inert atmosphere (Ar) the framework collapses at around 330 °C and forms a metastable amorphous phase which recrystallizes to a denser phase of zni topology (ZIF-zni(Zn)) at ~450-500 °C (crystallographic densities: ρZIF-4(Zn) = 1.18 g cm-3, ρZIF-zni(Zn) = 1.54 g cm-3). Melting of this ZIF-zni(Zn) phase is observed at ~590 °C and at approximately 600 °C the melted material decomposes. Mechanistically, ZIF amorphization, recrystallization and melting involves dynamic breaking and reformation of zinc-imidazolate bonds. Quenching the liquid ZIF to room temperature before reaching the decomposition temperature yields a ZIF glass, which still features Zn2+ ions that are tetrahedrally coordinated by imidazolate linkers, however, lacks long-range order. The structure of the ZIF glass was found to be analogous to the continuous random network model developed for silicate glasses.

elements.content: Further investigations revealed that a few other ZIF derivatives also melt at elevated temperatures and form glasses on vitrification. One important representative is ZIF-62­(M) (approximate composition M­(im)1.75(bim)0.25; M2+ = Zn2+, Co2+; bim– = benzimidazolate) which features the same cag topology as ZIF-4­(Zn) but about one-eighth of the im– linkers are replaced by the bulkier bim– linkers (). Surprisingly, this results in a much lower melting temperature of only ∼430–440 °C for ZIF-62­(M) and a much larger thermal stability window of its liquid phase (thermal decomposition at ∼600 °C for ZIF-62­(Zn) and ∼550 °C for ZIF-62­(Co) under Ar atmosphere). R. N. Widmer et al. very recently showed that ZIF-62­(Zn) features negative-Clapeyron-slope melting behavior, resulting in a decreased melting temperature by application of large hydrostatic pressures in the range from 2 to 4 GPa. A. Qiao et al. reported that ZIF-62­(Zn) derivatives with larger concentrations of bim– can be prepared. When increasing the molar amount of bim– per formula unit (x; formula unit Zn­(im)2–x (bim) x ) from x = 0.25 to 0.36 the melting point of the material increases slightly from 435 °C (x = 0.25) to 448 °C (x = 0.36). Bennett et al. suggested that the lower melting point of ZIF-62­(Zn) (with x = 0.25) compared to ZIF-4­(Zn)/ZIF-zni may be caused by the higher electron donating properties and the larger steric hindrance of bim–. However, the physical origin of the very different melting temperatures of these ZIF materials remains poorly understood.

elements.content: Herein we report an elaborate study on the influence of the concentration of the bulky bim– linker on the melting temperature and glass forming behavior of ZIF-62­(M) materials. The thermal phase behavior, physical properties and thermodynamics of melting of an extended series of 11 ZIF-62­(M)-bim x derivatives with varying im–:bim– ratios (general chemical composition M­(im)2–x (bim) x ; M2+ = Co2+ or Zn2+, x = 0.02–0.35) are thoroughly analyzed with single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD), (variable temperature) X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD), X-ray total scattering (pair distribution function analysis), IR and NMR spectroscopy, simultaneous thermogravimetric analysis/differential scanning calorimetry (TGA/DSC), as well as various gas physisorption measurements. By covering the entire range from regular ZIF-4 (x = 0) over the zone with low bim– concentration (0.02 < x < 0.24) to conventional ZIF-62 (x ≥ 0.25), we unveil a subtle transition from derivatives showing sequential amorphization/recrystallization (x < 0.05) to derivatives exhibiting coherent low temperature melting (x ≥ 0.05). Via adjusting x, the melting point of ZIF-62 can be lowered to only ∼370 °C, which marks by far the lowest melting point of a three-dimensional porous MOF discovered until now. Moreover, we demonstrate for the first time that the intrinsically microporous ZIF glasses can adsorb gaseous C3 and C4 hydrocarbons (i.e., propane, propylene, and n-butane). Surprisingly and despite their random network structure, thermodynamic and kinetic sorption data both indicate a preference for the adsorption of propylene over propane in the ZIF glasses, demonstrating the potential of these metal–organic glasses in propylene/propane separation (e.g., as monolithic glass membranes).

elements.content: ZIF-4­(M) and ZIF-62­(M)-bim x were prepared by adapting published protocols from the literature. M­(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mmol, 1.2 g) and varying ratios of imidazole and benzimidazole (total molar amount 13.2 mmol, molar ratios are given in and ) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) to yield a total volume of 90 mL. The obtained solution was divided in ten 9 mL portions, which were transferred into ten 12 mL borosilicate vials. The tightly sealed reaction vials were transferred to a preheated oven (100 °C for the Zn-based compounds, 130 °C for the Co-based compounds) for 7 d. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction volumes were recombined, filtered, and washed three times with 20 mL DMF. The ZIFs were obtained as large, truncated octahedrally shaped single crystals. After full characterization the as-synthesized materials were dried at 200 °C under dynamic vacuum (p ≈ 10–4 kPa) for 20 h to obtain the evacuated materials in the form of single crystals.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

ZIF-4(M) and ZIF-62(M)-bim x  were prepared by adapting published protocols from the literature. M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.0 mmol, 1.2 g) and varying ratios of imidazole and benzimidazole (total molar amount 13.2 mmol, molar ratios are given in  and ) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) to yield a total volume of 90 mL. The obtained solution was divided in ten 9 mL portions, which were transferred into ten 12 mL borosilicate vials. The tightly sealed reaction vials were transferred to a preheated oven (100 °C for the Zn-based compounds, 130 °C for the Co-based compounds) for 7 d. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction volumes were recombined, filtered, and washed three times with 20 mL DMF. The ZIFs were obtained as large, truncated octahedrally shaped single crystals. After full characterization the as-synthesized materials were dried at 200 °C under dynamic vacuum (p ~ 10-4 kPa) for 20 h to obtain the evacuated materials in the form of single crystals.

x = 2·c(bim–)/(c(im–) + c(bim–)), c = molar concentration.

ZIF-zni­(M) (M2+ = Co2+, Zn2+) was synthesized in analogy to a literature protocol. Imidazole (10 mmol, 680 mg) was dissolved in 3-methyl-1-butanol (15 mL) and a solution of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.245 g) or Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.098 g) in quinoline (15 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was equally split and transferred into two Teflon-lined autoclaves with a volume of 23 mL each. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 140 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained single crystals were washed with ethanol (3× 15 mL) and dried in air.

Imidazole (10 mmol, 680 mg) was dissolved in 3-methyl-1-butanol (15 mL) and a solution of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.245 g) or Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.098 g) in quinoline (15 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was equally split and transferred into two Teflon-lined autoclaves with a volume of 23 mL each. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 140 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained single crystals were washed with ethanol (3× 15 mL) and dried in air.

elements.content: Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) data of as-synthesized as well as evacuated (guest-free) ZIF crystals were collected on an Oxford Diffraction Xcalibur or a Bruker D8 Venture diffractometer using MoKα or CuKα radiation. A N2 cryostream from Oxford Instruments was used for the sample environment (T = 100–400 K). Further experimental details can be found in the . X-ray powder diffraction (XRPD) patterns were recorded on a Siemens D5005 diffractometer in Bragg–Brentano geometry with CuKα radiation in the range from 5° to 50° 2θ with a step size of 0.01° or 0.02°. Finely ground samples were deposited on a glass holder or a single crystal zero background sample holder made of silicon (cut along the (610) plane). Structureless profile fitting (Pawley method) were performed with the TOPAS academic v6 software. Variable temperature XRPD was performed at Beamline 9 of DELTA (Dortmund, Germany) with a monochromatic X-ray beam (λ = 0.6199 Å) using a MAR345 image plate detector. Finely ground samples were sealed in quartz glass capillaries, placed on an Anton Paar DHS1100 hot stage and heated under a polyether ether ketone (PEEK) dome. Temperature calibration of the hot stage was performed by reference XRPD measurements of α-quartz. X-ray total scattering was performed at beamline I15–1 of Diamond Light Source (UK) using a monochromatic X-ray beam (λ = 0.161669 Å, 76.7 keV). Finely ground samples were loaded into 1.5 mm (outer diameter) borosilicate capillaries. Scattering data from an empty capillary were used for background subtraction. Corrections for background, multiple, container and Compton scattering, as well as for absorption were done with the GudrunX program. The X-ray pair distribution functions (XPDFs) on the form of D(r) were obtained via Fourier transform of the normalized reciprocal space data (S(Q)). Simultaneous thermogravimetric analysis/differential scanning calorimetry (TGA/DSC) measurements were conducted on a STA504 instrument from TA Instruments (USA) under a constant argon flow (4 L h–1). A number of different temperature programs each with a scan rate of 10 °C min–1 were utilized (see for details). Infrared (IR) spectroscopy was carried out on a PerkinElmer SpectrumTwo FT-IR spectrometer (ν̃ = 400 cm–1 - 4000 cm–1) in reflection mode using a diamond ATR (attenuated total reflectance) unit. 1H NMR spectroscopy was performed on digested ZIF samples with Bruker DPX-300, DPX 500 or Agilent DD2 500 spectrometers using DMSO-d 6 (0.5 mL) and DCl/D2O (35 wt %, <0.1 mL) as solvents. The data were processed with the ACD/Labs software. Data were referenced to the residual proton signal of DMSO and chemical shifts are given relative to tetramethylsilane. Isothermal gas sorption experiments were performed with a Quantachrome iQ MP porosimeter. Prior to the first measurement the samples were degassed under dynamic vacuum (p ≈ 10–5 kPa) at 200 °C for 2 h. Between measurements, samples were degassed under dynamic vacuum (p ≈ 10–5 kPa) at ambient temperature for ∼3 h. Gas sorption isotherms were measured with N2 at 77 K, CO2 and n-butane at 273 K, propane and propylene at 273 and 293 K. Kinetic sorption data were collected for propane and propylene at 293 K by applying a gas pressure of ∼55 kPa and recording the pressure changes over time.

elements.content: Conventional ZIF-62­(Zn) has an idealized framework composition of Zn­(im)1.75(bim)0.25, proposing a molar ratio of im–:bim– of 7:1 in the solid state. Here, we applied varying im–:bim– ratios (from 7:1 to 210:1, ) and different metal ions (Co2+ or Zn2+) in ZIF synthesis to obtain an extended series of 11 ZIF-62­(M)-bim x derivatives of the general composition M­(im)2–x (bim) x (with x = 0.02–0.35, ). For comparison the bim–-free ZIF-4­(M) compounds (im–:bim– = 1:0; x = 0) were synthesized and studied as well. All compounds grow as large (0.2–1.0 mm) single crystals with a truncated octahedral morphology (colorless for Zn2+, deep purple for Co2+). The actual concentration of bim– in the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x materials was determined by solution 1H NMR spectroscopy of samples dissolved in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6 ( and ). It was found that bim– is incorporated preferentially in the framework, so that x is significantly larger in the framework solids compared to the amount applied in the synthesis mixture. This observation is in accordance with our recent study on ZIF-62­(Co) (with x = 0.30) and can be attributed to the higher acidic strength of Hbim (pK a = 12.78) compared to Him (pK a = 14.52). In order to check if the amount of bim– varies between different crystals from the same reaction batch, 1H NMR spectra were also recorded on several individual crystals of one batch. No variation of the im–:bim– ratio was observed, so we conclude that bim– is homogeneously distributed throughout the samples.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

ZIF Synthesis, Structural, and Compositional Characterization

Conventional ZIF-62(Zn) has an idealized framework composition of Zn(im)1.75(bim)0.25, proposing a molar ratio of im-:bim- of 7:1 in the solid state. Here, we applied varying im-:bim- ratios (from 7:1 to 210:1, ) and different metal ions (Co2+ or Zn2+) in ZIF synthesis to obtain an extended series of 11 ZIF-62(M)-bim x  derivatives of the general composition M(im)2-x (bim) x  (with x = 0.02-0.35, ). For comparison the bim--free ZIF-4(M) compounds (im-:bim- = 1:0; x = 0) were synthesized and studied as well. All compounds grow as large (0.2-1.0 mm) single crystals with a truncated octahedral morphology (colorless for Zn2+, deep purple for Co2+). The actual concentration of bim- in the ZIF-62(M)-bim x  materials was determined by solution 1H NMR spectroscopy of samples dissolved in DCl/D2O/DMSO-d 6 ( and ). It was found that bim- is incorporated preferentially in the framework, so that x is significantly larger in the framework solids compared to the amount applied in the synthesis mixture. This observation is in accordance with our recent study on ZIF-62(Co) (with x = 0.30) and can be attributed to the higher acidic strength of Hbim (pK a = 12.78) compared to Him (pK a = 14.52). In order to check if the amount of bim- varies between different crystals from the same reaction batch, 1H NMR spectra were also recorded on several individual crystals of one batch. No variation of the im-:bim- ratio was observed, so we conclude that bim- is homogeneously distributed throughout the samples.

elements.content: SCXRD at 100 K reveals that all as-synthesized materials are isomorphous (orthorhombic space group Pbca) and composed of M2+ cations, which are tetrahedrally coordinated by N-donor atoms of four different im– or bim– linkers, forming a 3D microporous framework of cag topology (). Two M2+ ions, four imidazolate linkers and about one DMF solvent molecule are present in the asymmetric units. The bim– linker could be localized at only one out of the four possible linker positions, causing this position to be occupied by 2x with bim– and 1–2x with im– depending on the chemical composition of the material. Remarkably, structure refinement of the evacuated, guest-free crystals (discussed below) revealed that the bim– linkers partially occupy not only one, but two of the four available imidazolate positions in the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x structures. The solvent accessible volume of the porous frameworks as estimated from the SCXRD structure data (DMF molecules omitted) amounts to 30–38% of the crystal volume (see section 4 of the for further details).
elements.clean_text: SCXRD at 100 K reveals that all as-synthesized materials are isomorphous (orthorhombic space group Pbca) and composed of M2+ cations, which are tetrahedrally coordinated by N-donor atoms of four different im- or bim- linkers, forming a 3D microporous framework of cag topology (). Two M2+ ions, four imidazolate linkers and about one DMF solvent molecule are present in the asymmetric units. The bim- linker could be localized at only one out of the four possible linker positions, causing this position to be occupied by 2x with bim- and 1-2x with im- depending on the chemical composition of the material. Remarkably, structure refinement of the evacuated, guest-free crystals (discussed below) revealed that the bim- linkers partially occupy not only one, but two of the four available imidazolate positions in the ZIF-62(M)-bim x  structures. The solvent accessible volume of the porous frameworks as estimated from the SCXRD structure data (DMF molecules omitted) amounts to 30-38% of the crystal volume (see section 4 of the  for further details).

elements.content: Before investigating their thermal properties (melting, glass formation and decomposition), the DMF-containing as-synthesized ZIF crystals were filtered off, washed thoroughly with fresh DMF and then dried at approximately 200 °C under dynamic vacuum (∼10–4 kPa) for 20 h. IR and solution 1H NMR spectroscopy () indicated that all compounds are DMF-free after this activation process, except for ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35, which still contained a small amount of DMF (∼0.04 molecules per formula unit) after the activation process (likely because of the narrow pore openings due to the large number of bim– linkers). The phase purity of all evacuated bulk materials was proven by XRPD (a) and established by structureless profile fitting of the obtained diffraction patterns ().

elements.content: TGA/DSC measurements under an Ar atmosphere were carried out on all evacuated ZIF-62­(M)-bim x materials in the range from room temperature to 750 °C (). Additional cyclic TGA/DSC experiments (three upscans, two downscans) were performed from room temperature to 475 or 510 °C (). In accordance with previous studies, the melting point (T m) is defined as the offset temperature of the calorimetric melting peak. Importantly, the TGA/DSC data show that T m of the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x decreases by about 70 °C from 440 °C for x = 0.35 to only 370 °C for x = 0.03 (b). Importantly, T m is largely independent of the utilized metal ion (Co2+ vs Zn2+) but a direct function of x (). The calorimetric signal for ZIF melting gets weaker and broader with decreasing x, signifying a slightly broader melting regime for the frameworks with lower values of x. Nevertheless, down to x = 0.03 the melting point of the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x materials clearly shows a linear dependence on x. Variable temperature XRPD experiments on a number of ZIF-62­(M)-bim x representatives support this observation (Figure S20–S26, , section 3).

In accordance with previous studies, the melting point (T m) is defined as the offset temperature of the calorimetric melting peak. Importantly, the TGA/DSC data show that T m of the ZIF-62(M)-bim x  decreases by about 70 °C from 440 °C for x = 0.35 to only 370 °C for x = 0.03 (b). Importantly, T m is largely independent of the utilized metal ion (Co2+ vs Zn2+) but a direct function of x (). The calorimetric signal for ZIF melting gets weaker and broader with decreasing x, signifying a slightly broader melting regime for the frameworks with lower values of x. Nevertheless, down to x = 0.03 the melting point of the ZIF-62(M)-bim x  materials clearly shows a linear dependence on x. elements.content: Cooling the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x liquids from 475 °C, above their T m, to room temperature (rate 10 °C min–1) yields their corresponding ZIF glasses, which all show clear evidence of macroscopic flow (d, ). These ZIF glasses will be further denoted as agZIF-62­(M)-bim x (ag signifies amorphous glass) with respect to their crystalline parent networks. XRPD indicates that all vitreous products are X-ray amorphous glasses for x = 0.05–0.35 (c). Supplementary X-ray pair distribution functions derived from X-ray total scattering data collected at beamline I15–1 of Diamond Light Source (UK) demonstrate that the local structure of the crystal and glass states of selected ZIF-62­(M)-bim x compounds (x = 0.05–0.35) are essentially identical (). Remarkably, the XRPD patterns of the vitreous products of the materials with the lower bim– content (i.e., ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.03 and ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.02) show Bragg peaks matching ZIF-zni­(Zn). Similar to ZIF-4­(M) (i.e., x = 0), these compounds partially recrystallize to ZIF-zni­(M) during the heating/cooling cycle (). The thermal behavior of ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.02 is indeed very similar to conventional ZIF-4­(Zn). No endothermic melting signal is observable in the DSC trace, but an exothermic peak for the recrystallization to ZIF-zni­(Zn) at ∼500 °C is evident (b). According to these data, the limit of coherent melting and formation of stable ZIF liquids that do not recrystallize to ZIF-zni­(M) lies around x = 0.05 for the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x system.

elements.content: The glassy nature of the agZIF-62­(M)-bim x materials (with x ≥ 0.03) was further verified by the presence of a glass transition in the second upscan of a cyclic TGA/DSC experiment (). The glass transition temperatures (T g, defined as the peak onset temperature of the endothermic calorimetric signal) of the ZIF glasses lies in the range from 290 to 320 °C for ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x and from 260 to 300 °C for ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x (, ). In accordance with previous theoretical studies, T g is also a function of x and increases slightly with increasing bim– concentration. The T g/T m ratio, a criterion for the glass forming ability (GFA), is in the range from 0.80 to 0.81 for the ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x derivatives and in the range from 0.83 to 0.88 for the ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials, which signifies the ultrahigh GFA across the series but in particular for the Zn-based compounds.

elements.content: compiles the molar enthalpies (ΔH m) and entropies (ΔS m) of melting determined from the DSC curves (first upscans). It is evident that ΔH m drops from 2.5 kJ mol–1 for ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35 to only 0.4 kJ mol–1 for ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.03. A similar trend is observed for ΔS m. ΔH m and ΔS m are a bit higher for the ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x materials compared to their Zn-based derivatives. We assume this is because of the slightly higher density of the Co-ZIFs (caused by the smaller ionic radius of Co2+ vs Zn2+). Nonetheless, the entropic difference between crystalline ZIF-62­(M)-bim x and its corresponding liquid gets lower with decreasing x, which suggests that the vibrational entropy of the porous crystalline phase gets almost comparable to the configurational entropy of the liquid phase. Noteworthy, ΔH m and ΔS m are about an order of magnitude larger for conventional ZIF-4­(Zn), because it melts from the much denser ZIF-zni­(Zn) phase and not from the porous phase of cag topology, as do the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x derivatives (with x ≥ 0.03).

elements.content: According to Lindemann’s law, bond dissociation (leading to reconstructive phase transitions, amorphization or melting) in a crystal is expected when the vibrational amplitudes of neighboring atoms reach a critical fraction of their bond distance. In order to investigate the evolution of dynamical atomic displacements of the molecular building units with temperature, we collected single crystal X-ray diffraction data of evacuated, guest-free crystals of selected ZIFs at various temperatures. For this purpose, we chose two ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x materials with very different bim– content (x = 0.30 and 0.10) as well as the isoreticular bim–-free derivative ZIF-4­(Co) and the denser polymorph ZIF-zni­(Co), both with x = 0. Complete data sets were collected at −173, −73, +27, and +127 °C (100, 200, 300, and 400 K) for all four compounds (see , section 4).
elements.clean_text:
Sequential Amorphization/Recrystallization vs Coherent Melting

According to Lindemann's law, bond dissociation (leading to reconstructive phase transitions, amorphization or melting) in a crystal is expected when the vibrational amplitudes of neighboring atoms reach a critical fraction of their bond distance. In order to investigate the evolution of dynamical atomic displacements of the molecular building units with temperature, we collected single crystal X-ray diffraction data of evacuated, guest-free crystals of selected ZIFs at various temperatures. For this purpose, we chose two ZIF-62(Co)-bim x  materials with very different bim- content (x = 0.30 and 0.10) as well as the isoreticular bim--free derivative ZIF-4(Co) and the denser polymorph ZIF-zni(Co), both with x = 0. Complete data sets were collected at -173, -73, +27, and +127 °C (100, 200, 300, and 400 K) for all four compounds (see , section 4).

elements.content: It is evident that the anisotropic displacement parameters (ADPs) of all atoms in the crystal structure are about 25–35% larger for the ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x materials compared to ZIF-4­(Co) at −173 °C (). This finding is explained by the presence of static atomic displacements caused by the incorporation of the bulky bim– linkers in place of im– in the frameworks of ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x . Remember that the bim– linkers are disordered throughout the crystal, which causes small distortions on a local scale. The evolution of the ADPs of each crystal structure with increasing temperature, nevertheless, gives valuable information on the dynamical atomic displacements and will provide insights into the melting/amorphization behavior of these compounds.

Remember that the bim- linkers are disordered throughout the crystal, which causes small distortions on a local scale. The evolution of the ADPs of each crystal structure with increasing temperature, nevertheless, gives valuable information on the dynamical atomic displacements and will provide insights into the melting/amorphization behavior of these compounds.

Co, N, and C atoms are shown in purple, blue, and gray. The dark gray C atoms are only partially occupied. H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: For the following discussion we concentrate only on the mean equivalent isotropic displacement parameters of the N atoms (U eq N) in the ZIF structures. The vibrational amplitude of these atoms is most important for the metal-linker bond dissociation which triggers the melting/amorphization process. Upon heating from −173 to +127 °C, U eq N increases by a factor of 2.4 for ZIF-4­(Co), while U eq N only increases by a factor of 1.8 for ZIF-62­(Co)-bim0.30 and 1.9 for ZIF-62­(Co)-bim0.10 (). This leads to the conclusion that the ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x materials are stiffer than ZIF-4­(Co) and that bond dissociation, as a consequence of large vibrational amplitudes, is expected at a lower temperature for ZIF-4­(Co), while the ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x compounds require a higher temperature. For comparison, the U eq N values of the denser ZIF-zni­(Co) are much lower than the corresponding values of ZIF-4­(Co) and ZIF-62­(Co)-bim x over the entire temperature range studied here, indicating that an even higher temperature is needed to trigger ligand-to-metal bond dissociation in ZIF-zni­(Co).

elements.content: Importantly, these findings are in accordance with the observation stated earlier in this paper that the ZIF-4­(M) materials amorphize at temperatures as low as 320–330 °C, while the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x compounds (with x ≥ 0.03) melt at higher temperatures between 370 and 440 °C. The thermal amorphization of ZIF-4­(M) generates a metastable disordered material, which recrystallizes to the thermodynamically stable ZIF-zni­(M) upon further heating. The ZIF-zni­(M) phase itself melts (for M2+ = Zn2+) or decomposes (for M2+ = Co2+) at even higher temperatures between 550 and 590 °C (). In agreement with our DSC data, the variable temperature SCXRD results suggest that bond dissociation (i.e., melting or amorphization) occurs at a higher temperature for ZIF-62­(M)-bim x compared to conventional ZIF-4­(M). As shown above, incorporation of the bulkier bim– linker in the framework efficiently suppresses the recrystallization to the ZIF-zni­(M) phase if x ≥ 0.05. Instead, the frameworks melt coherently and form ZIF liquids which are thermodynamically stable up to their decomposition temperature (510–600 °C). Thus, via fine-tuning x the melting point of ZIF-62­(M)-bim x can be drastically lowered and, at the same time, the thermal stability window of the liquid ZIF phase decisively increased. It is important that the formation of a stable ZIF liquid which does not recrystallize to ZIF-zni is already observed for very low bim– concentrations (i.e., about 1 bim– linker on 39 im– linkers, x = 0.05), far away from the conventional bim– concentration of the ZIF-62­(M) materials (i.e., 1 bim– linker on 7 im– linkers, x = 0.25).

elements.content: It is remarkable that so far (and including this work) melting has only been reported for ZIFs which contain the small im– linker. The well-studied ZIF-7, including only the bulky bim– linker (chemical composition Zn­(bim)2) does not melt. The same is true for ZIF-8 (Zn­(mim)2, mim– = 2-methylimidazolate) whose mim– linkers are only slightly larger than im–. Hence, the incorporation of im–, seems mandatory to achieve meltable ZIFs. Larger imidazolate-type linkers result in larger tetrahedral units enhancing steric hindrance and hampering melting. However, ZIFs featuring only the small im– (such as ZIF-4), do not form stable ZIF liquids at low temperature. ZIF-4­(Zn) as well as its polymorphs (e.g., ZIF-zeg, ZIF-nog) amorphize at 320–330 °C and subsequently recrystallize to ZIF-zni­(Zn). As outlined, ZIF-zni­(M) is highly stable and does not melt before ∼590 °C.
elements.clean_text: It is remarkable that so far (and including this work) melting has only been reported for ZIFs which contain the small im- linker. The well-studied ZIF-7, including only the bulky bim- linker (chemical composition Zn(bim)2) does not melt. The same is true for ZIF-8 (Zn(mim)2, mim- = 2-methylimidazolate) whose mim- linkers are only slightly larger than im-. Hence, the incorporation of im-, seems mandatory to achieve meltable ZIFs. Larger imidazolate-type linkers result in larger tetrahedral units enhancing steric hindrance and hampering melting. However, ZIFs featuring only the small im- (such as ZIF-4), do not form stable ZIF liquids at low temperature. ZIF-4(Zn) as well as its polymorphs (e.g., ZIF-zeg, ZIF-nog) amorphize at 320-330 °C and subsequently recrystallize to ZIF-zni(Zn). As outlined, ZIF-zni(M) is highly stable and does not melt before ~590 °C.

elements.content:
Nevertheless, on the basis of our experimental data we hypothesize that a great number of other ZIFs may melt at lower temperatures (i.e., much below 590 °C), form stable liquid phases (i.e., do not recrystallize to a denser phase) and transform into porous glasses upon cooling from the melt, as long as the following two requirements are fulfilled:

The ZIF must contain im– linkers and at least one other imidazolate-type linker that is bulky enough to prevent recrystallization to the ZIF-zni phase (as in the current case of ZIF-62­(M), the concentration of the bulky imidazolate linker may be remarkably low, however).

Naturally, the bulky imidazolate-type linker must feature a decomposition temperature higher than the framework’s melting temperature in order to allow melting before decomposition.

(ii) Naturally, the bulky imidazolate-type linker must feature a decomposition temperature higher than the framework's melting temperature in order to allow melting before decomposition.

Naturally, the bulky imidazolate-type linker must feature a decomposition temperature higher than the framework’s melting temperature in order to allow melting before decomposition.

The fact that amorphization (i.e., bond breaking and framework collapse) of ZIF-4­(M) occurs at 320–330 °C further suggests that the lowest melting point that is achievable for ZIFs at atmospheric pressure lies around this region. As shown above, incorporation of just small amounts of the bulky bim– linker results in a melting point of ∼370 °C, about 40–50 °C higher than the temperature of amorphization of ZIF-4­(M). Incorporation of functionalized imidazolate linkers that are smaller than bim– might however lead to the discovery of ZIFs with melting points approaching 320–330 °C.

elements.content: Importantly, the two requirements outlined above are already met by a number of known ZIF compounds. Melting and glass formation has previously been demonstrated for TIF-4 (Zn­(im)1.5(5-mbim)0.5, T m = 467 °C, 5-mbim– = 5-methylbenzimidazolate), ZIF-76 (Zn­(im)1.62(5-Clbim)0.38, T m = 451 °C, 5-Clbim– = 5-chlorobenzimidazolate) and ZIF-76-mbim (Zn­(im)1.33(5-mbim)0.67, T m = 471 °C) – strikingly, all of these frameworks fulfill the described requirements. Many other mixed-linker ZIFs satisfying at least the first requirement are known: ZIF-60, -70, -303, -360, -365, -376, -386, -486, -412, -413, -414, and -725. Future studies will show if these compounds indeed melt at elevated temperature. In analogy to what is presented here for the prototypical ZIF-62 system, it is very likely that T m of all of the mixed-linker ZIFs mentioned above can also be tuned systematically by adjusting the molar ratio of their two linkers.

elements.content: Until today, gas sorption properties have only been reported for very few ZIF glasses. These investigations just included gases such as H2, N2, CO2 and CH4 so far. Here, we performed elaborative gas sorption studies on three agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x representatives using N2 and CO2, as well as larger hydrocarbon gases, namely propane, propylene and n-butane. The selected agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x derivatives cover a wide range of compositions (x = 0.35, 0.17, and 0.05). elements.clean_text:
Gas Sorption Properties

Until today, gas sorption properties have only been reported for very few ZIF glasses. These investigations just included gases such as H2, N2, CO2 and CH4 so far. Here, we performed elaborative gas sorption studies on three agZIF-62(Zn)-bim x  representatives using N2 and CO2, as well as larger hydrocarbon gases, namely propane, propylene and n-butane. The selected agZIF-62(Zn)-bim x  derivatives cover a wide range of compositions (x = 0.35, 0.17, and 0.05). We chose x = 0.05 as the smallest x value, because this is the lowest bim- concentration allowing for coherent low temperature ZIF melting without recrystallization to ZIF-zni(Zn) from the melt.

elements.content: Similar to previous studies on conventional ZIF-62­(M) materials (i.e., with x = 0.25–0.30), CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K revealed that the agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials are all permanently porous against CO2 (). The uptake at ∼100 kPa is very similar (∼1 mmol g–1) for all three materials () and amounts to about 50% of the uptake of the corresponding crystalline parent ZIFs under the same conditions (). Importantly, the desorption branches of the CO2 isotherms of the glasses show only a very small hysteresis, suggesting that diffusion of CO2 in and out of the pore network of the ZIF glasses does not experience significant limitations when compared to their crystalline counterparts. In accordance with foregoing reports and contrary to the CO2 sorption data, the glasses only adsorb very small amounts of N2 at 77 K because of diffusion restrictions at cryogenic temperatures (). Cyclic CO2 sorption experiments on agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35 reveal that the sorption capacity of this representative glass does not decrease even after 11 consecutive ad-/desorption cycles (). XRPD and CO2 sorption data of a sample of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35, which was immersed in water for 24 h, indicate structural integrity after water treatment; solely a minor loss of porosity is evident ().

The uptake at ~100 kPa is very similar (~1 mmol g-1) for all three materials () and amounts to about 50% of the uptake of the corresponding crystalline parent ZIFs under the same conditions (). Importantly, the desorption branches of the CO2 isotherms of the glasses show only a very small hysteresis, suggesting that diffusion of CO2 in and out of the pore network of the ZIF glasses does not experience significant limitations when compared to their crystalline counterparts. In accordance with foregoing reports and contrary to the CO2 sorption data, the glasses only adsorb very small amounts of N2 at 77 K because of diffusion restrictions at cryogenic temperatures (). Cyclic CO2 sorption experiments on agZIF-62(Zn)-bim0.35 reveal that the sorption capacity of this representative glass does not decrease even after 11 consecutive ad-/desorption cycles (). XRPD and CO2 sorption data of a sample of agZIF-62(Zn)-bim0.35, which was immersed in water for 24 h, indicate structural integrity after water treatment; solely a minor loss of porosity is evident ().

Specific surface areas and pore size distributions were determined by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) fitting of the CO2 adsorption isotherms (). The specific surface areas for the agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials range between 235 and 269 m2 g–1, which is remarkably large for these collapsed and highly disordered MOF glasses. The specific surface areas of the crystalline ZIFs are about twice as large (439–504 m2 g–1). Pore size distributions indicate a complete loss of small cavities (diameter ∼3.5 Å) but significant preservation of medium sized cavities (diameter 5–6 Å) and even formation of new larger cavities (diameter ∼8 Å) upon melting and formation of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x .

elements.content: The comparatively large cavities of the porous ZIF glasses encouraged us to investigate for the first time their sorption properties toward larger hydrocarbon gases. Remarkably, gas sorption isotherms of n-butane at 273 K show indeed a considerable uptake of 0.7 to 0.8 mmol g–1 at saturation ( and ). In contrast to CO2 (kinetic diameter 3.3 Å), the sorption isotherms of n-butane (kinetic diameter 4.3 Å) possess significant hysteresis on desorption. Importantly, the hysteresis gets more pronounced with increasing x, which signifies that a larger concentration of the bulkier bim– linker reduces the diffusion rate of larger hydrocarbon gases, most likely via reduced pore aperture sizes.

elements.content: In order to access the potential of the agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials for the sorption and separation of technologically relevant hydrocarbons, we also investigated the sorption of propylene and propane in these microporous glasses. At both temperatures investigated (273 and 293 K) all glasses showed a preference for the adsorption of propylene over propane ( and and ). Ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) calculations based on the isothermal sorption data recorded at 293 K propose a (thermodynamic) propylene/propane selectivity (S IAST) between 1.8 and 2.5 (for a 1:1 mixture) for the ZIF glasses (, section 10).

Ideal adsorption solution theory (IAST) calculations based on the isothermal sorption data recorded at 293 K propose a (thermodynamic) propylene/propane selectivity (S IAST) between 1.8 and 2.5 (for a 1:1 mixture) for the ZIF glasses (, section 10).

elements.content: With the aim to get further insights into the C3 hydrocarbon sorption properties of the ZIF glasses, time-dependent sorption profiles for propane and propylene at 293 K were recorded after applying a gas pressure of ∼55 kPa ( and ). From the uptake-time profiles it is clearly evident that the diffusion of propylene into the glasses is much faster than the diffusion of propane. In the case of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.05 it takes almost five times longer for propane than propylene to reach 90% of its equilibrium uptake and for agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.17 it takes more than six times longer for propane than propylene to reach this uptake.

From the uptake-time profiles it is clearly evident that the diffusion of propylene into the glasses is much faster than the diffusion of propane. In the case of agZIF-62(Zn)-bim0.05 it takes almost five times longer for propane than propylene to reach 90% of its equilibrium uptake and for agZIF-62(Zn)-bim0.17 it takes more than six times longer for propane than propylene to reach this uptake.

elements.content: Furthermore, it is apparent that the diffusion rates of both C3 hydrocarbons strongly depend on x. Due to the larger concentration of bulky bim– linkers and hence narrower pores, agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35 exhibits a much slower kinetic sorption profile compared to the glasses with lower bim– concentrations. Propylene takes about three times longer to reach 90% of its equilibrium uptake if x = 0.35 compared to x = 0.17 or 0.05. For propane the differences in diffusion rates are much less pronounced across the series of ZIF glasses. This observation implies that the diffusion rates and thus the kinetic sorption selectivity of particular gases of interest (e.g., other hydrocarbons) could be optimized by adjusting the linker ratios in these nanoporous ZIF glasses.

Propylene takes about three times longer to reach 90% of its equilibrium uptake if x = 0.35 compared to x = 0.17 or 0.05. For propane the differences in diffusion rates are much less pronounced across the series of ZIF glasses. This observation implies that the diffusion rates and thus the kinetic sorption selectivity of particular gases of interest (e.g., other hydrocarbons) could be optimized by adjusting the linker ratios in these nanoporous ZIF glasses.

elements.content: Even though current crystalline benchmark MOFs feature much higher propylene/propane selectivities (S IAST up to ∼60) than the ZIF glasses investigated here, these first hydrocarbon sorption data for ZIF glasses are very encouraging for a future development of microporous MOF glasses as well as their blends and composites toward improved sorption properties and a higher gas separation power. The huge advantage of porous MOF glasses compared to their crystalline parent frameworks lies on the one hand in their very high thermal decomposition temperatures and on the other hand in their liquid phase processability. Recent work by S Li et al. showed that bubble-free monolithic bulk samples (i.e., pellets) of ZIF-62­(Zn) can be prepared via a melting/remelting technique. The absence of grain boundaries and interfaces in such bulk MOF glasses is deemed to facilitate mass transport and gas permeability. In future work, we envisage the preparation of grain-boundary-free ZIF glass membranes of variable shapes, exhibiting gas separation properties competitive to current MOF film on macroporous support or mixed-matrix technologies.

elements.content: We have synthesized a series of 11 different ZIF-62­(M)-bim x metal–organic frameworks composed of different metal ions (M2+ = Co2+ or Zn2+) and varying ratios of two different imidazolate-type linkers (the small im– and the bulkier bim–). Investigations toward their thermal behavior revealed that these mixed-linker ZIF materials of the general chemical composition M­(im)2–x (bim) x melt at elevated temperatures and form ZIF glasses by cooling the liquid ZIFs down to ambient temperature. It was found that the metal ion (Co2+ vs Zn2+) has a major impact on the decomposition temperature (∼510–550 °C for the Co-ZIFs, ∼550–600 °C for the Zn-ZIFs) but only minor on the frameworks’ melting point. The melting point of the ZIF compounds, however, can be engineered over a wide range between 440 and 370 °C by simply adjusting the molar ratio of im– to bim– in the solid state. Remarkably, the melting point of the ZIFs is linearly dependent on the concentration of bim– in the material, resulting in a melting point of only 370 °C for x = 0.03, a record low for the melting temperature of a 3D porous MOFs. ZIFs containing low concentrations of bim– (x < 0.05) form a metastable liquid phase that partially recrystallizes to the denser ZIF-zni at about 500 °C. On the contrary, ZIFs containing higher concentrations of bim– (x ≥ 0.05) form thermodynamically stable liquids which do not recrystallize to the ZIF-zni phase.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have synthesized a series of 11 different ZIF-62(M)-bim x  metal-organic frameworks composed of different metal ions (M2+ = Co2+ or Zn2+) and varying ratios of two different imidazolate-type linkers (the small im- and the bulkier bim-). Investigations toward their thermal behavior revealed that these mixed-linker ZIF materials of the general chemical composition M(im)2-x (bim) x  melt at elevated temperatures and form ZIF glasses by cooling the liquid ZIFs down to ambient temperature. It was found that the metal ion (Co2+ vs Zn2+) has a major impact on the decomposition temperature (~510-550 °C for the Co-ZIFs, ~550-600 °C for the Zn-ZIFs) but only minor on the frameworks' melting point. The melting point of the ZIF compounds, however, can be engineered over a wide range between 440 and 370 °C by simply adjusting the molar ratio of im- to bim- in the solid state. Remarkably, the melting point of the ZIFs is linearly dependent on the concentration of bim- in the material, resulting in a melting point of only 370 °C for x = 0.03, a record low for the melting temperature of a 3D porous MOFs. ZIFs containing low concentrations of bim- (x < 0.05) form a metastable liquid phase that partially recrystallizes to the denser ZIF-zni at about 500 °C. On the contrary, ZIFs containing higher concentrations of bim- (x ≥ 0.05) form thermodynamically stable liquids which do not recrystallize to the ZIF-zni phase.

elements.content: Even though only a few ZIFs containing the small im– linker have been shown to melt so far, our data clearly demonstrate the impact of the bulkier bim– linker on the frameworks’ melting point as well as on the formation of thermodynamically stable ZIF liquids. We hypothesize that a large number of literature-known crystalline ZIFs also melt as far as they are composed of im– linkers and at least one other bulkier imidazolate-type linker. This sets the stage for the development of a large number of new functional and chemically diverse ZIF glasses. Moreover, the low melting point of the ZIFs with x ≈ 0.05–0.10 further opens the door for the lower temperature preparation of MOF glass composites incorporating temperature sensitive compounds (e.g., metal-organic or organometallic complexes, organic fluorophores, etc.).

We hypothesize that a large number of literature-known crystalline ZIFs also melt as far as they are composed of im- linkers and at least one other bulkier imidazolate-type linker. This sets the stage for the development of a large number of new functional and chemically diverse ZIF glasses. Moreover, the low melting point of the ZIFs with x ~ 0.05-0.10 further opens the door for the lower temperature preparation of MOF glass composites incorporating temperature sensitive compounds (e.g., metal-organic or organometallic complexes, organic fluorophores, etc.).

elements.content: Importantly, we also prove for the first time that the glasses of the ZIF-62­(M) family are not only porous toward small gas molecules such as CO2, but also toward larger C3 and C4 hydrocarbons. Adsorption isotherms and time-dependent sorption profiles indicate that the ZIF glasses are an interesting new class of materials for the separation of propylene from propane. Together with the advantages of ZIF glasses in terms of processability and shaping as well as their very high thermal decomposition temperatures, our findings pave the way for applications of ZIF glasses in composite membranes or even as free-standing glass membranes for technologically important separation processes.

cln_elements.content:
ZIF-4­(M) and ZIF-62­(M)-bim x were prepared by adapting published protocols from the literature. M­(NO3)2·6H2O (4.0 mmol, 1.2 g) and varying ratios of imidazole and benzimidazole (total molar amount 13.2 mmol, molar ratios are given in and ) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) to yield a total volume of 90 mL. The obtained solution was divided in ten 9 mL portions, which were transferred into ten 12 mL borosilicate vials. The tightly sealed reaction vials were transferred to a preheated oven (100 °C for the Zn-based compounds, 130 °C for the Co-based compounds) for 7 d. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction volumes were recombined, filtered, and washed three times with 20 mL DMF. The ZIFs were obtained as large, truncated octahedrally shaped single crystals. After full characterization the as-synthesized materials were dried at 200 °C under dynamic vacuum (p ≈ 10–4 kPa) for 20 h to obtain the evacuated materials in the form of single crystals.

ZIF-zni­(M) (M2+ = Co2+, Zn2+) was synthesized in analogy to a literature protocol. Imidazole (10 mmol, 680 mg) was dissolved in 3-methyl-1-butanol (15 mL) and a solution of Co­(OAc)2·4H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.245 g) or Zn­(OAc)2·2H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.098 g) in quinoline (15 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was equally split and transferred into two Teflon-lined autoclaves with a volume of 23 mL each. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 140 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained single crystals were washed with ethanol (3× 15 mL) and dried in air.

Experimental Section

Synthesis

ZIF-4(M) and ZIF-62(M)-bim x  were prepared by adapting published protocols from the literature. M(NO3)2⋅6H2O (4.0 mmol, 1.2 g) and varying ratios of imidazole and benzimidazole (total molar amount 13.2 mmol, molar ratios are given in  and ) were dissolved in N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) to yield a total volume of 90 mL. The obtained solution was divided in ten 9 mL portions, which were transferred into ten 12 mL borosilicate vials. The tightly sealed reaction vials were transferred to a preheated oven (100 °C for the Zn-based compounds, 130 °C for the Co-based compounds) for 7 d. After cooling to room temperature, the reaction volumes were recombined, filtered, and washed three times with 20 mL DMF. The ZIFs were obtained as large, truncated octahedrally shaped single crystals. After full characterization the as-synthesized materials were dried at 200 °C under dynamic vacuum (p ~ 10-4 kPa) for 20 h to obtain the evacuated materials in the form of single crystals.

ZIF-zni(M) (M2+ = Co2+, Zn2+) was synthesized in analogy to a literature protocol. Imidazole (10 mmol, 680 mg) was dissolved in 3-methyl-1-butanol (15 mL) and a solution of Co(OAc)2⋅4H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.245 g) or Zn(OAc)2⋅2H2O (5.0 mmol, 1.098 g) in quinoline (15 mL) was added. The mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. Subsequently, the reaction mixture was equally split and transferred into two Teflon-lined autoclaves with a volume of 23 mL each. The autoclaves were sealed and heated to 140 °C for 24 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained single crystals were washed with ethanol (3× 15 mL) and dried in air.

cln_elements.content:
Similar to previous studies on conventional ZIF-62­(M) materials (i.e., with x = 0.25–0.30), CO2 sorption isotherms at 273 K revealed that the agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials are all permanently porous against CO2 (). The uptake at ∼100 kPa is very similar (∼1 mmol g–1) for all three materials () and amounts to about 50% of the uptake of the corresponding crystalline parent ZIFs under the same conditions (). Importantly, the desorption branches of the CO2 isotherms of the glasses show only a very small hysteresis, suggesting that diffusion of CO2 in and out of the pore network of the ZIF glasses does not experience significant limitations when compared to their crystalline counterparts. In accordance with foregoing reports and contrary to the CO2 sorption data, the glasses only adsorb very small amounts of N2 at 77 K because of diffusion restrictions at cryogenic temperatures (). Cyclic CO2 sorption experiments on agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35 reveal that the sorption capacity of this representative glass does not decrease even after 11 consecutive ad-/desorption cycles (). XRPD and CO2 sorption data of a sample of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35, which was immersed in water for 24 h, indicate structural integrity after water treatment; solely a minor loss of porosity is evident ().

Specific surface areas and pore size distributions were determined by nonlocal density functional theory (NLDFT) fitting of the CO2 adsorption isotherms (). The specific surface areas for the agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x materials range between 235 and 269 m2 g–1, which is remarkably large for these collapsed and highly disordered MOF glasses. The specific surface areas of the crystalline ZIFs are about twice as large (439–504 m2 g–1). Pore size distributions indicate a complete loss of small cavities (diameter ∼3.5 Å) but significant preservation of medium sized cavities (diameter 5–6 Å) and even formation of new larger cavities (diameter ∼8 Å) upon melting and formation of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x .

The comparatively large cavities of the porous ZIF glasses encouraged us to investigate for the first time their sorption properties toward larger hydrocarbon gases. Remarkably, gas sorption isotherms of n-butane at 273 K show indeed a considerable uptake of 0.7 to 0.8 mmol g–1 at saturation ( and ). In contrast to CO2 (kinetic diameter 3.3 Å), the sorption isotherms of n-butane (kinetic diameter 4.3 Å) possess significant hysteresis on desorption. Importantly, the hysteresis gets more pronounced with increasing x, which signifies that a larger concentration of the bulkier bim– linker reduces the diffusion rate of larger hydrocarbon gases, most likely via reduced pore aperture sizes.

cln_elements.content: (a) XRPD patterns of the evacuated ZIF-62­(M)-bim x derivatives. The diffraction pattern simulated from the crystal structure of ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim0.35 is shown for comparison. (b) DSC upscans of the evacuated ZIF-62­(M)-bim x materials. The black arrows indicate T m. The asterisk (*) marks the exothermic signal for the recrystallization to ZIF-zni­(M). (c) XRPD patterns of the materials obtained via heating the ZIF-62­(M)-bim x derivatives to 480 °C followed by cooling to room temperature. The diffraction pattern simulated from the crystal structure of ZIF-zni­(Zn) is shown for comparison. (d) Photographs of a representative single crystal of ZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x (top) and glass pieces of agZIF-62­(Zn)-bim x (bottom). The scale bars indicate a length of 200 μm. Data of the zinc- and cobalt-based ZIFs are shown in blue and purple, respectively.
